unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: Type I Error
question_text: A type I error is best described as an error result in

choices.text: Not rejecting a true null hypothesis.
Not rejecting a false null hypothesis.
Making two successive incorrect statistical decisions in two independent experiments.

solution:
Choice 'A' is correct; if the null hypothesis is true, you would not want to reject it. At a set $\alpha$-level (alpha), for example $ \alpha =0.05$, you are essentially saying that if an “unusual” experimental result occurs, one that would happen by chance only $5\%$ of the time or less, then this would be grounds to reject the null hypothesis.

However, occasionally ($5\%$ of the time, to be exact) an unusual result occurs even when the null hypothesis is true. The null hypothesis will be mistakenly rejected even though it is true. This is a type I error, and its probability is always equal to the value that is set for $\alpha$.

Choices 'B' and 'C' are incorrect; these describe correct statistical decisions, not errors.

Choice 'D' is incorrect; it describes a type II error, with probability $\alpha$.

Choice 'E' is incorrect; type I and type II errors relate to a single hypothesis test.
